status_notes: Case Noted. Please do not move the watering bag. The watering bag was properly installed by the planting contractor to the specifications set forth by the City Arborist. The watering bag should be installed around the tree stake itself and not the trunk of the tree. This is done to prevent the trunk of the tree from being damaged by the wet conditions that the watering bag creates around the trunk as well as to encourage new root growth outside of the root ball. If you have any further questions or comments please contact the Park Line at 617-635-7275.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. National Grid is installing a new gas main. The City encourages this type of capital upgrade work.  It will provide dependable gas service to the residents as well as eliminate future emergency repairs. The City acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. However in the long run the placement of a new gas main is well worth it.  National Grid has to install the gas main first.  Once the main has been installed, then all service connections can be made. If the City were to make National Grid pave to grade each day's trench work, it would cause multiple seams along the trench. More importantly, every service connection needs to be cut into the trench.  If we were to pave the trench every day, this would result in 2 by 2 patches inside the trench area, resulting in a very poor final product. In order to have the best final paving, the City allows the utility company to leave the trench down low until all service connections are made and then pave the trench all at once, resulting in a smooth, and level final trench repair. . Service laterals are topped within 24 hours of excavation. What the constituent is observing is the trench left down low in preparation for one continuous final paving operation. We do require that the contractor place florescent orange signs ahead of the construction informing motorists that the trench ahead is down low. The work is expected to be completed within 2 weeks. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Noted. The watering bags were properly installed by the planting contractor to the specifications set forth by the City Arborist. The watering bags should be installed around the tree stake itself and not the trunk of the tree. This is done to prevent the trunk of the tree from being damaged by the wet conditions that the watering bag creates around the trunk as well as to encourage new root growth outside of the root ball. The contractor is responsible to water the tree once every 2 to 3 weeks, but the City also relies heavily on residents to help water the tree. If you have any further questions or comments please contact the Park Line at 617-635-7275.

status_notes: Case Noted. The Boston Transportation does its best to maintain a steady flow of traffic throughout the day and evening. We make adjustments to signal timing when applicable to help improve traffic flow. We also alert the Boston Police and/or the Massachusetts State Police of when there may be an irregular flow of traffic. We are able to view certain areas of the City through a live feed from cameras to our Traffic Management Center; which allows us to make adjustments to the signal timing. We do not however have the authority or the capability to make signal adjustments to traffic signals owned by other authorities. The City of Boston and the Transportation Department apologize for any inconvenience the traffic congestion has caused you. If you have any questions or concerns, or would like to discuss this issue further, please do not hesitate to contact us using the Mayor’s 311 mobile app service.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. . The Boston Public Works Department Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) has identified the sidewalk left in asphalt as belonging to National Grid. . Sidewalks are required to be restored within 60 days. . The location has been entered into the CIU data base that tracks repairs to be made by utility companies or private contractors. . If at anytime the asphalt patch becomes unacceptable before the concrete restoration is made National Grid will be required to make all necessary repairs. . The CIU will monitor the progress of the repair. . Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
